explanation:
memcpy — The potential MISRA violation centers on the memcpy call. Need the exact prototype/semantics to confirm that copying name_len bytes does not read/write beyond the source (record->name_entry) or destination (buffer) bounds.

OS_strnlen — The code uses OS_strnlen to determine name_len. Must know its exact behavior (equivalent to POSIX strnlen? upper bound semantics?) to ensure it cannot read past the allocated storage for name_entry when the stored name lacks a NUL within the limit.

OS_common_record_t (definition) — The structure layout is required to know how name_entry is represented (inline array vs pointer, element type) and any inherent bound on the stored name.

record->name_entry (type/allocation/maximum length) — Critical to know whether name_entry is a pointer to a buffer of known size or an inline fixed-size array (and its maximum capacity). If name_entry points to a buffer smaller than buffer_size, OS_strnlen(record->name_entry, buffer_size) could read beyond its allocation; if it is fixed-size, that size gives an absolute bound for safe reads/copies.

OS_ObjectIdGetById — Provides the token/lock and indicates whether obtaining the object is successful. Its contract must be known to ensure the returned token makes the record pointer valid and stable for the subsequent read (prevents concurrent free/resize).

OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken — Returns the record pointer from the token. Need its contract to confirm that the returned record pointer references memory with valid name_entry storage for the duration of the token.

OS_ObjectIdRelease — Understand when the token/lock is released and ensure accesses to record->name_entry occur only while the token is held; confirms no use-after-release.

OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl — Used to select the object type for OS_ObjectIdGetById. Object type might affect whether name_entry exists or its encoding/size; include to reason about which object kinds can be passed and whether they guarantee name semantics.

OS_CHECK_POINTER — This macro/function validates the buffer pointer. Its semantics (does it return on NULL, abort, or do nothing in some builds) affect whether buffer[0]=0 is safe.

OS_CHECK_SIZE — Validates buffer_size. Need to know if it enforces buffer_size>0 (so buffer[0] and buffer[name_len] accesses are safe) or returns an error otherwise.

OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG — Error-code constants to understand control-flow and whether the function returns early in error cases; not directly about memory safety but necessary to reason about which branches execute and when copies occur.

osal_id_t, OS_object_token_t — Type definitions for the id and token are required to interpret the OS_ObjectIdGetById/Release contracts (e.g., whether token is an opaque handle and lifetime guarantees).

These symbols together let an analyst determine: (1) whether OS_strnlen can safely probe record->name_entry for up to buffer_size bytes without reading past its allocation, (2) whether memcpy(buffer, record->name_entry, name_len) reads/writes within valid source/destination ranges, and (3) whether the object token/locks ensure the name storage remains valid during the read/copy. Without these definitions/semantics you cannot conclude compliance with the MISRA rule regarding out-of-bounds string handling.
